qas.question: What element of On the Origin of Species ensured that the book would be taken seriously by scientists?

answers.text: its dryness ensured that it was seen as aimed at specialist scientists and could not be dismissed as mere journalism or imaginative fiction.

qas.question: What did On Origin of Species avoid in order to raise its chance of being taken seriously?

answers.text: it avoided the narrative style of the historical novel and cosmological speculation

qas.question: What reason did David Quammen believe that On the Origin of Species was weakened in later editions?

answers.text: Darwin making concessions and adding details to address his critics

qas.question: Why did James T. Costa think that On the Origin of Species was more likely to draw interest than a larger book that Darwin had been working on?

answers.text: because the book was an abstract produced in haste in response to Wallace's essay

qas.question: Why did James T. Costa think the larger, abandoned book would not have been as successful?

answers.text: would have been encumbered by scholarly footnotes and much more technical detail

context: While the book was readable enough to sell, <a0_0>its dryness ensured that it was seen as aimed at specialist scientists and could not be dismissed as mere journalism or imaginative fiction.<a0_0/> Unlike the still-popular Vestiges, <a1_0>it avoided the narrative style of the historical novel and cosmological speculation<a1_0/>, though the closing sentence clearly hinted at cosmic progression. Darwin had long been immersed in the literary forms and practices of specialist science, and made effective use of his skills in structuring arguments. David Quammen has described the book as written in everyday language for a wide audience, but noted that Darwin's literary style was uneven: in some places he used convoluted sentences that are difficult to read, while in other places his writing was beautiful. Quammen advised that later editions were weakened by <a2_0>Darwin making concessions and adding details to address his critics<a2_0/>, and recommended the first edition. James T. Costa said that <a3_0>because the book was an abstract produced in haste in response to Wallace's essay<a3_0/>, it was more approachable than the big book on natural selection Darwin had been working on, which <a4_0>would have been encumbered by scholarly footnotes and much more technical detail<a4_0/>. He added that some parts of Origin are dense, but other parts are almost lyrical, and the case studies and observations are presented in a narrative style unusual in serious scientific books, which broadened its audience.
